What's happening is that the doSave method on the editor is failing, perhaps
because another save is underway or because the editor is not in a state where
it can be saved.  The two offending bits of Mylar code now check to see if the
save is allowed and if the editor is dirty before invoking the save.  Although
this should resolve the report, I'm curious about what caused this since I haven't
seen it before.  Do you have any wierd Java editors around, or did this happen
with a normal one?

I'm using 3.2M1 with AJDT, WDT and Spring IDE plugins. There wasn't any AJDT
code opened in the editors, so I guess they were all standard editors.

Wow, I think that makes you the ultimate early adopter!  At least in my eyes,
since those are my favorite technologies :)  I haven't used WDT though, what do
you use it for, JSPs?  Prefer it to WTP?  I'm curious since I at oen point Mylar
should start doing a better job on enterprise app resources.

The fix I put it should fix this bug no matter what the editor, but please raise
it again if you ever get a similar message (the AspectJ editor does some unusual
things in the background).

(In reply to comment #3)
> Wow, I think that makes you the ultimate early adopter!  At least in my eyes,
> since those are my favorite technologies :)  I haven't used WDT though, what do
> you use it for, JSPs?  Prefer it to WTP?  

  Actually it is WTP. It is quite easy to get lost in these actonyms...

> I'm curious since I at oen point Mylar
> should start doing a better job on enterprise app resources.

WTP is needed for last Spring IDE (for app context XML editor).

I not really use WTP's JSP editor, because I can't move to that sily project
layout (and because of that JSP editor can't recognize any tags). So, it is all
old-fashioned hot-deployment and I'm using XML editor for JSP too.

I also have simple plugin that allow to start WebLogic inside Eclipse (but
remote debugger work almost as good as that plugin).

> The fix I put it should fix this bug no matter what the editor, but please raise
> it again if you ever get a similar message (the AspectJ editor does some unusual
> things in the background).

Thanks Mik. I'll keep an eye on this.
